problem_text:
19.79. (T. Springer). Let G be a group. Suppose that for every integer n > 0 the
group G has a unique (up to isomorphism) irreducible complex linear representation
of dimension n. (Note that G = SL(2, Q) has these properties, by a theorem of Borel–
Tits (Ann. Math., 97 (1973), 499–571).) Is it true that G has a normal subgroup N
such that G/N is isomorphic to SL(2, Q)?
J.-P. Serre
